title: Facile Synthesis of Cyclic Peptide–Phthalocyanine Conjugates for Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor-Targeted Photodynamic Therapy

reactions.text: The bifunctional linker 1 was prepared by treating 1,3,5-tris(bromomethyl)benzene with one equiv of sodium cyclopentadienylide. For the photosensitizer part, a zinc(II) phthalocyanine core was used due to its superior photophysical properties and high photostability. To facilitate the coupling through the cyclopentadiene moiety of the linker, a maleimide unit was introduced to the phthalocyanine. With an electron-deficient and sterically unhindered π system, maleimide serves as an excellent dienophile. Compared to furan and 2,4-hexadiene derivatives, maleimide has a much higher reactivity toward cyclopentadiene and the resulting endo cycloadduct also has a higher thermal stability which does not undergo the retro-Diels–Alder reaction below 275 °C. Moreover, the Diels–Alder cycloadducts are generally more stable in serum than the maleimide–thiol conjugates formed via Michael addition.

The conditions of peptide cyclization were first optimized for the reaction of EBP and 1,3-bis(bromomethyl)benzene. Various peptide concentrations and solvent systems were used, and the yield of the product was determined by reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). As shown in Figure S1 in the Supporting Information and Table 1, the use of a mixture of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and NH4HCO3 buffer (pH 8.0) (1:1 v/v) as a solvent could lead to the formation of cyclic peptide 3 in 74 and 55% HPLC yield after 2 h when a peptide concentration of 0.5 and 1 mM was used, respectively. Some side products were also formed in this reaction.

After stirring at room temperature for 2 h, the reaction was essentially completed as shown by the disappearance of the signals due to the two starting materials and the occurrence of a strong signal assignable to the cyclopentadiene-functionalized cyclic peptide 4 (Figure 2c), which was characterized with MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). Without isolating the intermediate product, 2 (2 mM) was added and the resulting mixture was stirred continuously overnight. The target conjugate 5 formed via the Diels–Alder reaction was obtained in 95% HPLC yield (Figure 2e).

The other two conjugates 6 and 7 were also prepared by the same protocol using the linear peptides RPM and TCP-1, respectively, as the starting materials (Figure 3). The results were similar to those for the preparation of 5 (Figures S5 and S6 in the Supporting Information and Table 2). All the intermediate and final products were also characterized using MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry (Figures S7–S10 in the Supporting Information).

The other two conjugates 6 and 7 were also prepared by the same protocol using the linear peptides RPM and TCP-1, respectively, as the starting materials (Figure 3). The results were similar to those for the preparation of 5 (Figures S5 and S6 in the Supporting Information and Table 2). All the intermediate and final products were also characterized using MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry (Figures S7–S10 in the Supporting Information).
